American Journal of Therapeutics 0, 1–3 (2022)

Complete Heart Block in a Patient Treated With Metoprolol,
Diltiazem, Omeprazole, and Escitalopram
To the Editor:
One of the leading causes of mortality and morbidity is adverse drug reactions, which can lead to numerous complications and prolonged hospital stays. In
2016, the estimated cost of prescription drug–related
morbidity and mortality was more than $528 billion in
the United States.1–3 Here, we discuss the importance
of clinician awareness of potential medication interactions and the increased risk of adverse events
because of multidrug interactions.
A 55-year-old woman with a medical history significant for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) status
postalcohol septal ablation 3 years prior and chronic kidney disease stage 3 presented to our emergency department with complete heart block with a heart rate of 26
bpm and blood pressure of 76/52 mm Hg (Figure 1A).
She had no history of syncope or ventricular

arrhythmias. She was given atropine and started on
transcutaneous pacing and subsequently transitioned to
norepinephrine and dopamine with improvement in her
heart rate and blood pressure (Figure 1B). Troponin was
0.01 ng/mL (reference range: 0.00–0.04 ng/mL), and an
echocardiogram during this admission showed global
hyperdynamic left ventricular systolic function with a
calculated 2D ejection fraction of 82%, increased proximal interventricular septal thickness, and turbulent flow
across the left ventricular outflow tract with a peak gradient of 35 mm Hg and maximum velocity of 3.00 m/s
because of the hyperdynamic state. There were no
regional wall motion abnormalities.
Review of her home medications revealed that her
daily metoprolol dose was 300 mg. She also takes longacting diltiazem 360 mg daily, omeprazole 20 mg
daily, and escitalopram 20 mg daily, which was

FIGURE 1. (A) Electrocardiogram on arrival showing a heart rate of 26 bpm and complete heart block. (B) Electrocardiogram after atropine and initiation of transcutaneous pacing and norepinephrine and dopamine infusions. Demonstrates
sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 51 bpm.
1075–2765 Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. All rights reserved.

www.americantherapeutics.com

Copyright © 2022 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. Unauthorized reproduction of this article is prohibited.

 2

Letters to the Editor

FIGURE 2. Effect of the interactions between metoprolol, diltiazem, escitalopram, and omeprazole on metoprolol
levels.

increased from 10 mg to 20 mg several weeks before
presentation. Several drug interactions to take note of
include those between metoprolol and escitalopram,
metoprolol and diltiazem, and escitalopram and omeprazole (Figure 2). One research article suggests that
escitalopram results in a 2-fold to 3-fold increase in the
bioavailability of metoprolol, while omeprazole may
increase escitalopram levels by 50%–100%.4,5 Furthermore, it is well-documented that the combination of
metoprolol and diltiazem can further increase the risk
of atrioventricular block (AVB) compared with diltiazem alone because of their synergistic effect. In addition, in patients with chronic renal failure, diltiazem
concentrations can be increased by 25%.6,7
Metoprolol is a widely used medication in the treatment of angina, atrial fibrillation/flutter, heart failure,
hypertension, and myocardial infarction. It predominantly
antagonizes b1-adrenergic receptors with minimal to no
effect on b2-adrenergic receptors at oral doses of less than
100 mg. However, with increasing plasma concentrations,
metoprolol’s relative b1-selectivity decreases and b2adrenergic receptor blockade increases, particularly at
plasma concentrations greater than 300 nmol/L.8,9
The increasing metoprolol plasma concentrations
because of concomitant usage of diltiazem and escitalopram in the setting of an already high dose of metoprolol
and known history of HCM likely precipitated our
patient’s episode of third-degree AVB. Although she had
been on a steady dose of 300 mg of metoprolol daily for
almost 3 years, we hypothesize that the prolonged duration
between onset of combined therapy and presentation may
be multifactorial because of the relatively recent doubling
of her dose of escitalopram in the setting of some degree of
pre-existing AVB and conduction disturbance because of
her history of HCM.6,10 Her clinical presentation did not
suggest any other cause for her third-degree AVB.
As patients are started on new medications or have
their medication doses adjusted, it is imperative for
clinicians to identify potential interactions between
the newly prescribed or adjusted medication(s) and
the pre-existing medications on their medication list.
American Journal of Therapeutics (2022) 0(0)

This will ultimately help decrease the rate of adverse
events related to multidrug interactions and prevent
possibly fatal outcomes.
Stephanie L. Ong, BS1
Mohammad Yassen, MD2
Sameh Syed, MD3
Ragheb Assaly, MD3
1
College of Medicine and Life Sciences, University of
Toledo, Toledo, OH
2
Department of Internal Medicine, University of
Toledo Medical Center, Toledo, OH
3
Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care, and Sleep
Medicine, Department of Internal Medicine,
University of Toledo Medical Center, Toledo, OH
The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.
Consent for publication: Patient provided consent.
